Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Industrial combustion optimization using machine learning to reduce emissions and increase fuel efficiency
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will result from development of an artificial intelligence optimization system that can be applied to any industrial combustion system. The simulator component of the proposed system will allow operators to run fast, low-cost experiments on large facilities without disrupting operations, and the optimizer component will recommend equipment settings to reduce fuel costs and emissions while maintaining performance. As a result, the system can potentially have a major impact on US energy and manufacturing markets, making American firms more competitive worldwide while simultaneously reducing the generation of harmful pollutants. Areas of application include energy generation, cement production, steel manufacturing, and mining operations.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project promises to significantly advance the understanding of complex industrial combustion processes. Currently, control models use inaccurate assumptions that create operational inefficiencies, resulting in wasted fuel and increased emissions. This project proposes a new paradigm for combustion research that combines the theoretical rigor of chemistry and thermodynamics with the data-adaptive flexibility of machine learning. The primary contributions of the company’s novel analytics pipeline include a simulator that enables operators to run in silico experiments on their facilities and an optimizer that maximizes combustion efficiency with more accurate controls, saving operators’ time and reducing fuel costs. These models leverage causal information about the facility to train a nonparametric regression ensemble that learns the plant’s behavior over time. The proposed project will fund the development of a three pillars analytics pipeline: unsupervised data exploration, supervised plant simulation, and customized optimization. This approach combines well established scientific principles with state-of-the-art machine learning techniques to build fast, flexible, and accurate simulators of power plants and other industrial facilities. With these models, analysts can run in silico experiments to optimize thermal efficiency and train algorithms to recommend ideal plant settings in real-time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this STTR project was to establish a new paradigm for combustion research that combines the theoretical rigor of chemistry and thermodynamics with the data adaptive flexibility of machine learning.

For this Phase I project, we developed a novel analytics pipeline that enables operators to run in silico experiments on their facilities, minimize harmful pollutants, and maximize combustion efficiency with more accurate controls.

Our technology will reduce fuel costs and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Taken together, these achievements will have a major impact on US energy and manufacturing markets, making American firms more competitive worldwide while simultaneously reducing the spread of harmful pollutants.

In realizing our technical goals, we accomplished the following specific objectives: (1) Observation. Data was gathered from a dedicated facility under a wide array of experimental conditions to train models and establish baseline distributions. (2) Exploration. Unsupervised learning pipelines were developed to ensure quality control, visualize trends, and prepare for supervised learning. (3) Simulation. Ensemble models were trained and tested on clean datasets to evaluate the accuracy and precision of predictions. (4) Optimization. A combustion optimizer was developed from a combination of observed and simulated data, providing real-time recommendations for optimal airflow.

Primary outcomes of this research to date include: (1) collecting and curating a high-quality dataset of over 140,000 observations spanning a diverse array of experimental conditions; (2) designing state-of-the-art simulations that outperform all previously reported combustion prediction models; and (3) in-silico optimization results indicating potential NOx reductions of 14.3%, CO reductions of 4.6%, PM reductions of 8.2%, and thermal efficiency gains of 4.4% on average. 

For combustion research, the present project represents a compelling synthesis of classical methods, which are primarily driven by thermodynamic equations, and data-driven alternatives, epitomized by supervised learning algorithms. We show how the two approaches, often misrepresented as independent or even antithetical, can in fact be combined to achieve results that neither could accomplish on their own. The result will have a major impact on how industrial systems are simulated and optimized.

Within the realm of data science, we demonstrate a novel, principled pipeline with potential applications to any area where data can be reliably modelled, simulated, and optimized. The methodological impact will only deepen as we continue to expand the range of algorithmic function classes from regression trees, which have proven especially powerful in this setting, to arbitrary alternatives such as kernel methods and recurrent neural networks.

As a direct result of this STTR project, ThermoAI won a pilot with Burlington Electric Department on their biomass power plant in Vermont during a DeltaVT. In addition, ThermoAI was the 2020 Grand Prize $1 Million Winner of 76West Clean Energy Competition.

Our experiments demonstrate how advanced machine learning techniques can complement models built on thermodynamic equations to save time and money for plant operators in industrial combustion settings. Minimizing pollutants and maximizing thermal efficiency will serve to increase the competitiveness of American workers in sectors such as energy, cement, and food production.
